questions.question: Why must we think before we speak? (Variant 51)
questions.answer: Because words cannot be taken back later.

questions.question: What lesson does the torn paper story teach? (Variant 52)
questions.answer: Words spread and cause effects that can't be reversed.

questions.question: Why did Socrates ask three questions? (Variant 53)
questions.answer: To prevent useless or hurtful talk.

questions.question: What happens if words are spoken angrily? (Variant 54)
questions.answer: They hurt people and damage relationships.

questions.question: Why did the girl fail to collect the torn paper? (Variant 55)
questions.answer: Wind scattered the torn pieces everywhere.

questions.question: What do words have the power to do? (Variant 56)
questions.answer: They can heal, harm, motivate or destroy.

questions.question: Why does the lesson praise silence sometimes? (Variant 57)
questions.answer: Because silence prevents careless mistakes.

questions.question: What role does truth play in speech? (Variant 58)
questions.answer: It forms the base of meaningful communication.

questions.answer: Whether it is true, kind and needed.

questions.question: Explain the lesson taught by the torn paper activity. (Insight 151)
questions.answer: The scattered papers represent spoken words. Once released they cannot be gathered again, teaching us to choose words carefully.

questions.question: Describe how Socrates’ three-question test helps prevent harm. (Insight 152)
questions.answer: Socrates suggests speech should be true, kind and necessary. Thinking through these filters stops rumours, gossip and careless harm.

questions.question: Why is speech compared to scattered feathers or paper pieces? (Insight 153)
questions.answer: Because scattered things cannot be recollected. Similarly, careless speech once spoken spreads beyond control and causes lasting effects.

questions.question: Discuss the meaning of ‘silence is golden’ with examples from the lesson. (Insight 154)
questions.answer: Sometimes being silent is wiser than reacting quickly. The girl’s activity and Disraeli’s quotation show silence saves us from regret.

questions.question: How do words affect relationships and society? (Insight 155)
questions.answer: Words can heal, encourage or inspire—but they can also injure, insult or divide. Responsible speech builds trust and unity.
